text: On a heavily shadowed street, two enemy Guards patrol a tactically important village block. Inside the most Prominent building, a party is in Progress, music wafting out into the street. The two Guards meet at a corner near the party's entrance, one loaning a cigarette to the othe Then they reverse their directions, walk apart, the Secon Guard disappearing into the darkness of the night. Titles begin. Suddenly, Jack Flack, everything a spy should be, swoops into view, riding a square American-flag parachute down from a nearby rooftop. Red, white, and blue cut through the darkness as he lands directly on top of the First Gua The parachute envelops them both. Two bodies thrash withi the silk. A moment later, Flack steps out, glances down t empty street. He wears a pair of tight pants and a beauti fully cut brown leather jacket, molded perfectly to his broad shoulders, tapering to a tight fit around his slend waist. . He pushes a hidden button on his jacket, and, with a whoo the parachute repacks itself instantly back into the jack showing not even a Lump. TITLES “CONTINUE. ©” The Second Guard turns around, heads back toward the part building. Jack Flack strolls nonchalantly up to the Second Guard, w challenges him.
(in Russian) Halt! Identify yourself. A moment of tension is followed by Jack Flack suavely responding by pulling out a silver cigarette case, gettin out a cigarette.
(in impeccable Russian) Do you have a light?

The Second Guard looks suspicious, pumps the action on hi rifle. Jack Flack blows a feather-tufted poison dart from his cigarette and into the neck of the Second Guard, who instantly stumbles and falls. TITLES CONTINUE. An expensive period limo pulls up. Out of it steps a villainous Iranian (with an uncanny resemblance to Khomei arm-in-arm with the lovely Lady Gillingham, a voluptuous Englishwoman. They are followed by a fat Soviet diplomat, who carries a thin black briefcase chained to his right arm. From the shadows, Flack makes his move: just as the black bag is passing him, he whips out a cord from his Jack Fla spy watch, with the same action used to start a chainsaw. Indeed, he is starting a chainsaw, a miniature one. Its tiny but effective blade running from his watch to his other hand. He instantly cuts through the chain, grabs th black bag, and the flexible saw retracts back into his watch. The Iranian lunges at him with a scimitar. Flack deftly kicks the knife high into the night sky, then Kung Fu kic the Iranian! Lady Gillingham draws a Luger from a bra holsterette, fires at Flack, who cleverly doffs his official hat with the shiny bulletproof-steel inner liner He holds the hat shield between himself and the bullet, causing it to ricochet off and plant itself right between Lady Gillingham's beautiful eyes. The Russian diplomat pulls one of those bowling ball-type bombs out of his pocket, its fuse already burning. He tesses it at Flack, whose spy drill kit Presents itself. instantly drills three holes in the burning bomb, inserts his fingers into it, and, exhibiting pro bowler prowess, bowls it at the diplomat and a group of soldiers, who are running in pin formation to his aid. The bomb explodes, sending them flying. Jack Flack knows enemy reinforcements are on the way, so ducks around the corner, the prized black bag safe in his hands. TITLES CONTINUE.
is halfway down the alley nonchalantly carrying the black case when suddenly a huge steel gate seems to slam down f the sky, sealing off the alley ahead of him.

As Jack wheels and starts back the way he came, the earth rumbles beneath his feet. The source of the rumble becomes immediately clear, as tw monstrous twenty-sided, brightly colored geometric forms come rolling around the corner and directly at Flack. Frantically, the spy again reverses his direction, runs f his life back toward the newly dropped steel gate. Credits end as Flack seems destined to be crushed by the frightening geometric boulders. But just then, in the nick of time, Jack Flack is invisib lifted out of the scene. MATCH DISSOLVE To

Camera pulls back to reveal Davey Osborne, eleven, doing the lifting. He is excited about the succes of his roll of brightly colored geometric dice.

(eagerly) What happens next, Morris?
Let's leave it there for now. I'll have to come up with something better to get you with. Anyway, I gotta work on the game. Davey looks hopefully to Kim to help him convince Morris keep playing.

We could trade. I'll give ya extra gas masks and a bulletproof vest. -

Davey walks away, gestures for her to follow, just as another elevator dings its arrival. Kim hesitates, finall follows Davey. Opbst and Haverman get on the elevator, having taken no further notice of the kids.

Hello? Hello? But there is no response. Davey keeps his radio with him, continues his climb.

Kim stands before the Receptionist, who hands her six videogame mailers.

(smiling) The vending machines are right around that corner. Kim nods her thanks and departs, mortified.
Davey is still climbing, now lowering the antenna on his radio, aware that he has been shut off by his partner. He looks miffed. From 0.S. comes a strong, resonant male voice.

Your friend cut off radio contact, did she? Davey stops, sees Jack Flack materialize out of thin air. He looks real and man-sized. He's just as winded as Davey but he's everything a spy should be, at least as a child would imagine it: tall and slender, wearing a black turtl neck and leather jacket with a bulge under the armpit whe his Walther PPK hangs ready and waiting. But it is his face that is most distinctive. Chiseled granite with two cold, pitiless eyes.
Oh, hi, Jack.
Some people just don't know how to act on a secret mission. We're better off handling this one on our own.
Yeah, I guess so. Davey follows Jack Flack up the stairs. Both spies draw their Walther PPKs and proceed. (Xx)

This reminds me of my assignment down in Maracaibo... (pause) We were surrounded by hordes of angry mercenaries...all I had on me was my switchblade and a ball of string...What's the matter? Flack notices that Davey has lost interest in the story ( momentarily. The boy is distracted as he notices in the opposite mirrored building that Jack has no reflectio Then Jack notices, trying to make out what had Davey's interest outside. They continue climbing.  12
Davey turns the landing, starts up the stairs toward the eighth floor. We no longer see Flack. Davey freezes, staring up at the dying man, Murdoch.

Murdoch sees Davey and stumbles to a halt, reaching out t support himself against the boy, causing Davey's backpack spill much of its contents: the lead Jack Flack, his soft ball, his bottle of Monster Blood, his radio, etc. Murdoc stares at the frightened boy. He speaks in a death rattle his eyes burning into Davey.
Help me --- The boy can only stare at him in horror. Murdoch grabs hi shoulder. He thrusts a tape cartridge into Davey's hand.

(dying) Here. Whatever happens, don't let them get it. They have to be stopped. Davey glances down to find a Donkey Kong game cartridge i his hand. Before he can ask any questions Murdoch speaks through a cough that flecks the side of his mouth with bl

{pushing Davey down the stairs) Run! Suddenly two silent slugs slam into the dying man. They whip him around and catapult him back first ever the stai way railing. As Davey watches in horror, Murdoch's body falls seven flights down the stairwell, bouncing off railings and walls to land with a sickening thud at the bottom, far below. Davey looks up to see where the shots came from. Peering down at him from a railing on the floor above are Haverma and Opbst, the two men from the elevator. Opbst has a Lug with a silencer on it in his hand, still smoking. He aims at the boy, about to fire. Davey grabs his backpack and whatever spilled items he ca quickly salvage, missing the softball. He whirls and plunges down the stairs, spoiling Opbst's shot. The killers bound down the steps after him.  13

It's more a refuge than it is a bedroom. The walls are dotted with fantasy posters, the shelves filled with mode airplanes, tanks and fantasy role-playing games like Dungeons and Dragons, Traveller, and Blitzkrieg. The plac of honor on the desk is taken up by an Atari and a TV. Davey sits in front of a dresser mirror Playing with toy soldiers. After a moment, there is a soft knock on his door. Davey doesn't respond. A moment later, the door creaks open. Davey's father peers in.
Ready to talk? Davey sits up. Hal joins him on the bed.
Now...tell me about the spies. (X)

One of 'em was real big. Like a giant. (x) The other one looked kind of Mexican or something. (pause) One of ‘em had a .38. I saw it up close. The other one had a Luger. And they both had silencers. (accusingly) You don't believe me....

(at his most - vulnerable, sobbing) I miss Mommy! 7/22/83 18 often and He throws his arms around his father, who holds him tight rocks him tenderly.

Davey closes right up.
Jack Flack was right. You do think I'm crazy.
No, Davey. Not crazy. But you're under a lot of strain. Anybody would be. That's...that's why you sometimes...talk to yourself. Hunh?

No! Davey digs into his backpack.

"Donkey Kong,' right? With a flourish, he pushes the Play button. Both Hal and Davey await a dramatic revelation. Davey goes into the game, the electronic little boy on th screen trying to climb the cliff while Donkey Kong holds the damsel in distress above him and rolls boulders down the boy. As the singsong game music Plays, Davey shoots glances at his father, while trying to play the game and discover its secret.
"Game Over" flashes on the screen, and Hal walks to the door with an armful of games.
Wait, Dad! Let me try again. Hal, sad and impatient, walks to the TV, uses the pile of games to push its Off button.

But....
Dammit, Davey! I said no and I mean no. Now get ready for bed. Sadly, Hal starts to exit the room.
(mumbling in utter frustration, seething) I hate you! Hal stops, hurt in his eyes. He puts the games down on Davey's bed, takes a deep breath, sees Davey red-faced an in.emotional knots. Sse .
(tenderly) I know you don't mean that, Davey.
(poutily) You don't care about me. You never believe me. Never! Ever!
(moving closer) Davey...I know how you feel....
(moving away) No, you don't!

There's a lot of me in you, Davey. More than I like to see. When I was your age, I looked at things the way you do. (mocking pride) That's why I joined the Air Force. So IT could fly planes! Wear a uniform! Be somebody! I wanted to be a hero. Davey looks puzzled.
(softening) But you were a hero in the war, Dad.
(arm around Davey) No, I wasn't, Davey. I just did my job.

Y'know,. when you grow up...you change. (X%) Lord knows it took me long enough to grow up, and settle down...and have you. One of the first things I found different is...real heroes don't shoot bad guys. Real heroes put supper on the table. They fix your bike. Every- day stuff. Boring stuff. The stuff nobody else wants to do, but everybody has to do. Now, I'm putting these games away. I don't want you playing with them anymore.
Dad, if you'd just play one with me sometime....
Good night, Davey. (X) Hal gets up, picks up the pile of games, walks out of the room. Jack Flack is suddenly there, sympathizing with Davey.
He's kinda dumb for an Air Force officer, isn't he?
Shut up.
Davey angrily hurls his toy Jack Flack across the room, t flesh-and-blood version having vanished.
Ouch! Suddenly, the phone in the hallway rings. Hal's voice echoes out of his bedroom. .
Get that, will you, Davey?
Davey picks up the phone. Through the open doorway into his father's room, he can see Hal packing the games he to into a chest of drawers.
(into phone) Hello?
(almost friendly) Is this David G. Osborne? Davey doesn't recognize the voice.
Yes. Davey just stands there, frightened.
Dad! Hal glances up as he closes the drawer on the role-playin games, thinking he's done with them forever.
What?
It's the spies. The ones who killed that man! Hal strides quickly down the hall, takes the phone from Davey's hand. Disbelief is evident in his eyes.
(into phone) Hel ---
There is evidently no one there. All he hears is a dial tone.
Did you hang up on someone?
(hurt, outraged) No! They hung up on me!
What did they say?
Nothing. They just asked who I was. (frightened) They know my name, Dad.
Davey...it was probably just a wrong number. Now, let's get you into bed! Hal takes him in his arms and holds the boy as close as h can, crooning soothingly in his ear.
Davey, Davey. It's all right. There's no reason to be upset --- Davey starts to cry, trying to crawl even closer into his dad's arms.
(through his tears) But, Dad, it was them. I know it was ---
(softening) You're just tired. It's way past your bedtime. He takes a step toward Davey's bedroom. The boy clings to his father's neck even tighter.
Can I sleep in your bed tonight?
(knowingly) Okay. If it makes you feel better.  20 21 22 23 and 24
Hal lays Davey gently in bed, staring down at his son.

(yawning) Those guys won't dare come in with you here. Davey is close to sleep as Hal watches. He pulls the covers over him and gazes down at his son. Davey's eyelids flutter closed. Hal kisses him gently on the cheek and walks to the light, snapping it off as he leaves the room, Plunging it into darkness.

Two cars sit in the street opposite Davey's condo, a shin black van and a pearl white Cadillac, Inside the Cadillac, Rice can be seen replacing a car Phone. He gets out and walks back to the van. Opbst sits behind the wheel, Haverman next to him peering through a pair of binoculars. Rice stops opposite Opbst, nods at th condo.
He's in there.
(lowering binoculars) So's his old man.
Now what do we do?
We wait. He and Opbst continue to stare at the condo. Haverman resumes his surveillance with the binoculars.
EXT. DAVEY'S HOUSE - pay 22 Early morning sunshine bathes the neighborhood. It's another bright summer day. 23 and 24

Davey bursts out the front door, stopping his father just as he's about to climb into his old Mustang. Hal Osborne is dressed in an Air Force Master Sergeant's uniform, obviously on his way to report for duty. He stops and turns back as his son rushes up to him.
Dad! Dad!
What is it, Davey?
Don't leave!
Davey, I have to go to work. I don't have any choice.
They're just waiting for you to leave so they can get me. Hal looks around the neighborhood. No sign of strangers. Absolutely nothing looks amiss.

But there isn't time --- The Guard behind her forces her gently back into her seat Kim looks at him like she'd like to kill him. The camera dollies in on the walkie-talkie poking out of her backpac the second hand on the overhead wall clock ticking away.

He tears hi eyes away, glancing at his watch. Five minutes left till the bomb goes off. He looks up and down the terminal, desperately searching for some sight of Kim.
(in midst of bureaucratic interview) Did they just call my name?
(preoccupied with paperwork) I wasn't listening. What was your mother's maiden name? Do you know - What that means?..... toe oe me
I think they said 'Kim Gardener.' That's me...!
Just a couple more questions....

The MacCreadys have just passed through the checkpoint an are walking toward the entrance to the boarding area as Davey skids to a halt before the guards, the metal detect to one side with a waiting line behind it.
Pardon me, have you seen a girl about eight? She's got blonde hair and....

He keeps glancing around even as he talks, hoping to catc sight of Kim. Suddenly he see the MacCreadys walking with stately steadiness toward their boarding area. Davey suddenly stops talking, pointing at them, and shouting.
Stop them! The MacCreadys turn and stare at the boy as Davey tries t dash around the X-ray machine only to be snagged by one o the guards.
Just a second there, son. Davey frantically struggles to free himself, still pointi at the MacCreadys who watch him with looks of frozen horr on their faces.
But they've got the tape ---+
I'm sorry, son, but you can't pass through here without being searched first. Who you with anyway?
(hopping up and down with frustration) But the tape ---

(pushing him back) Now you'll just have to go around to the other side of the metal detector like everyone else =--- Davey looks at the long line. By the time he is searched and passes through the machine, the MacCreadys will be lo gone. They know that, too, and turn to go on their way. Davey watches them go, not knowing what to do for a moment. Suddenly he wails at the MacCreadys like some long, lost child.

Mom, Dad, please, don't leave me! The MacCreadys freeze again, glancing back as the Guard turns around to look at them. They hurry on their way, suddenly wishing they were invisible. The Guard turns bac to Davey.
(bewildered) They your folks? Davey stands there, watching the MacCreadys getting furth and further away.

Yes, sir, and they told me to wait in the car. They said they'd be right back. Only I knew they were lying. They're leaving me behind forever! The Guard suddenly turns and calls loudly after the MacCreadys.
Just a minute there, folks. Would you mind comin' back here. The MacCreadys stop, exchanging glances. George turns to the Guard, doing his best to smile.
But our plane’s boarding ---

It'll wait. Let's get this straightened out first. Holding Davey by the hand, he walks him toward the MacCreadys, the couple walking back to meet them. Everybody is now glancing at them curiously. They all sto opposite each other, the Guard nodding down at Davey.
This your boy?
(sarcastically) (X) Of course not! Do we look like we'd have children that age? The Guard looks down at Davey, none too pleased.
You putting me on, boy?
(more innocent than apple pie) No, sir. I don't know why they're doing this, but I can prove they're my folks.
How?
He uw Davey turns an angelic smile on the MacCreadys. He points to the camera bag hanging off of George's shoulder.
If you look inside that bag, you'll find one of my electronic game tapes, Donkey Kong. The Guard looks up at George and holds out his hand.
Could I see your bag, sir.
(getting very uncom- fortable suddenly) But I assure you, officer, this boy's lying. We've never seen him before in our lives.

I've still got to see that bag. Now, please, give it to me. Furious, George glowers down at Davey. Davey gives hima huge smile in return. George's eyes snap to the trash can with his pistol in it on the other side of the metal detector, suddenly wishing he hand't ditched it. Suddenly the security office door to the side of the checkpoint opens and Kim steps out followed by the Chief Security and the Guard that originally took her in there. She sees Davey and yells at the top of her lungs.
Davey! He whirls, seeing her at the same time. They take off on the run for each other.

Kim, quick, give me the walkie- _talkie --- George and Eunice glance up. All they see is a little gir rushing toward them followed by two security guards. Thinking they've been discovered, George goes crazy. He smashes the Guard beside him across the chest with his overnight case, slamming the man back against the wall. A the man slumps to the floor stunned, George grabs his gun of his holster and whips it up, pointing it at the approa security guards.
Stand back!

Before she can say anything, he rips her backpack off, Pa through it, and grabs the walkie-talkie. He looks around wildly for somewhere to get rid of the bomb. He sees a door behind the MacCreadys with a glowing "Exit" sign abo it. He vaults the inspection area stand and dashes for it George reaches out and snags Davey on the way, throwing a choke hold on the boy and using him as a body shield between himself and the guards, yelling at them as he hol the gun to Davey's head.
Now just stay where you are!

(struggling to get free, holding up the walkie-talkie) But this thing has a bo(mb) -- ! (x) George tightens his hold on Davey's neck, cutting off his words and most of his air. The boy gasps as he's dragged backward by George, Eunice beside him, the gun and the hostage holding the guards at bay.
othe ‘terminal’ He “and Marilyn” jump out just as two police cars pull up, disgorging a battalion of cops led b Lt. DioGuardia. They all dash for the terminal.
George and Eunice back into the crowded waiting area, George's gun still held to Davey's head. People back away from them as the Ticket Agent intones boarding instructio
We will begin boarding passengers rows one through twenty~seven -~-- The Ticket Agent stops as he becomes aware of the commotion. He comes out from behind his dais, heading toward the MacCreadys.
What's going on here --- ?

George turns and shoots the man in the leg as he gets too close. He goes down as people all around them panic, screaming and clawing to get away from the MacCreadys. Holding the gun to Davey's head, George drags the boy acr the lounge, his wife beside him. All three disappear out the door onto the tarmac and up the portable stairs into the waiting 727 jet.
Hal and Marilyn wait while a policeman questions the chec out girl. Fleming talks to them.

We found two dead men by the river. Another one two blocks away. Turns out they were wanted by the FBI for selling military secrets on the international market. They were smuggling them out in children's video game cartridges. Hal looks tremedously quilty when he hears the last line.
What about Davey?

(solemnly) We've got divers down there now. ™ (pulls something ~ out of his pocket) We did find this though. Did it belong to your son? Hal takes the mutilated lead figure of Jack Flack from th lieutenant, clutches it in his hand.
God! Why didn't I believe him.... Marilyn comforts him. The policeman returns to Fleming wi news.
Come on!
They skid to a halt before the empty lounge, already cord off by airport security men holding pistols trained on th
waiting jet outside. Lt. Fleming hurries over to the (X) Security Chief, flashing his badge at the man.
Fleming, Homicide.
A man and a woman just kidnapped a boy. They're holding him hostage inside the plane ---~ Marilyn rushes to Kim, her arms outstretched. (X)
Kim! She runs across the cordoned-off area and sweeps her daug up in her arms.
Oh, Kim, Kim, I was so worried about you ---

(pointing through the window to the waiting plane) They've got Davey in there! Marilyn turns to stare at the 727 sitting out there on th tarmac, then walks back toward Hal as DioGuardia and the Security Chief leave him alone to go about business on th own.
What did they say?
(nodding at the jet outside) If they don't get a pilot to fly them to Cuba in the next five minutes... they're going to kill him.
(in disbelief) No...they wouldn't.... oo Hal hurries across the lounge to where the Security Chief and DioGuardia stand.
What are you going to do?
The FBI is sending a team over. They SN chee chin retina aed lee URES a pLhote who! s thr adne situations like this.
How long before they get here?
(hating to admit it) A few minutes. I just called them.
(exploding) A few minutes may be too late. That's my boy in there --- A member of the ground crew enters from the outside.
He says we've got three minutes before they.... The crewman sees Hal, stops what he was about to say.
(forcing it out) Before they kill him? The crewman looks to the Chief, then to Hal, reluctantly nods.
He's bluffing.
He's bluffing with my kid's life. (grabbing the Chief's shouder) Let me go.
What?
I'm a Staff Sergeant at Kelly in charge of ground crews. I'm licensed to taxi planes ---
Forget it.

That's out of the question. I'm sorry. Tell him there's a pilot coming out. Hal keeps the radio, starts for the door.
Come back here. (to DioGuardia) Stop him. We could lose our ass in a lawsuit.

George shoves Davey away from tne door, Eunice by his sid

His eyes widen with panic as he realizes just how alone he is And he sits there, surrounded by the silence, staring at the bomb with its impossible profusion of wires sitting o his small lap, the seconds ticking away inside the digita display, the counter showing there are only three minutes to go. Hal slips into the pilot's seat and begins to run a check on the instrument panel as George stands over him, the crete gone SOD. EEBANOS. OR DES RAG ag ea wy oe nate in r
Hal hits a red button and George's ears pop. He digs a finger into one of them trying to ease the pain and digs his gun into Hal's back.
What was that?
Pressurizing the cabin --- He continues to check the instruments without missing a beat.
Davey is staring worriedly at the guts of the bomb, bitin his lower lip, the penknife poised in his hand, the secon ticking away on the digital display, even as he watches.

Outside the window, the wing jets leap to life, revving a making the entire plane shudder as they warm up. Davey keeps his gaze on the impossible profusion of wires in th walkie-talkie, pounding his good leg in his frustration.

Oh...oh... (suddenly really frightened) Help me, Jack.... Tears of hopelessness start to roll down Davey's face. 150-C INT. COCKPIT - NIGHT 150-c Hal reaches nervously for the radio mike. George reacts suspiciously.
I have to get take off clearance.
Davey is close to tears.
Oh, Jack, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to throw you away ---
Hal feels something uncomfortable on his seat. It is in his back pocket. He pulls out the damaged figure of Jack Flack, pauses a half instant, then repockets it in his shirt.
(on radio mike, to tower) Attention, tower. This is flight one-four-six requesting permission - to taxi te runway one-five, for immediate reroute to Havana.
Permission granted, one-four-~six. Now, without George seeing him, we see Hal push the intercom button on the radic mike.
Suddenly Hal's Voice comes over the intercom from the cockpit.
This is Captain Jack Flack. Will Davey Osborne please come forward to the cockpit. Stunned, Davey stares toward the forward cabin as he recognizes the voice.
As Hal sets the mike down, George jams his gun muzzle dee into his ribs. Hal groans in pain from his seat in the pilot's chair.

What's the big idea? You don't need to see the kid.

Orders. I'm not supposed to take (X) off until I make sure he's safe. George stares at him furiously. Hal returns his gaze, refusing to drop his eyes. George finally whirls and shouts out the cockpit door in Eunice's direction.

Get him up here. (%) (whirling back on Hal) And no funny business from you. He jams the gun into the back of Hal's neck, both men waiting for the boy to appear, Hal revving the huge jets outside the windows, bringing them up to full power and beyond. “o
Eunice walks down the plane toward Davey.

But...but it's going to go off in (X%) less than a min ---

March, junior! Now!! (X) She clears the seat and stops above him, getting her firs look at the bomb. It's a very good one: the plastique, the wires, the ticking time counter, all of it are sudden visible to her. She freezes with fear and screams.
“~~ George! George! The bomb's digital counter is clicking away even as she watches, 068, 067 ---

George! He takes off on a run out of the cockpit. Hal grabs the microphone again, yelling into it.
Davey, get up here quick!
Davey takes off down the aisle, leaving Eunice, staring a the bomb and still screaming. it keeps ticking, 060, 059
George! Davey gets halfway down the plane when George suddenly appears from the front section. They almost collide, the spy collaring the boy and dragging him to a halt.

Oh, no, you don't --- Davey struggles to free himself, but he doesn't have a chance against the stronger adult. INT. COCKPIT - NIGHT i55 Hal rises from his seat, ¢raning his neck to see back dow the passageway into the interior of the Plane. At the midsection, he sees. Davey struggling.in George's grasp. falls back into his seat, throttling all jets full open a releasing the brake.

Marilyn, her daughter Kim, Lt. DioGuardia, all the cops a security guards stand with their noses pressed to the glass, staring at the huge jet just outside the first-flo window of the lounge. The plane suddenly shudders and lurches forward.
(pointing excitedly) Look, it's moving! The jet leaps directly toward them, gaining speed at a frightening rate, tearing loose from the boarding ramp an throwing it aside.  157 158 159

The sudden movement throws George back against the wall o the plane, causing him to lose his grip on Davey. As the plane straightens, gaining speed, the boy leaps to his fe and dashes toward the cockpit. George heaves himself erect, about to spring after Davey. Eunice screams at him from farther back in the plane as she picks herself up fr the floor where she fell.

Forget the boy and get back here! INT. AIRPORT BOARDING LOUNGE - NIGHT i58 The huge jet tears right toward the window; suddenly it turns a hard right, its enormous left wing swinging in a huge are directly toward the window.

Duck! Everybody hits the floor as. the plane wheels about on a dime, its wing barely missing the window. Everybody leaps to their feet, staring out the window at the 727 roaring down the runway away from them, gaining more and more speed with every passing second. Kim suddenly leaps forward, climbing through the window, and out onto the runway, tearing across the tarmac after the plane.
Davey --- Her mother leaps after her, dashing down the runway tryin to catch her daughter.
Kim!
Eunice and George stand staring down at the bomb on the seat. She turns to him, barely able to control her panic.
Well, disarm it. ©
George manages to pull a wire loose, but nothing happens.
(turning to her helplessly) I don't know how. A terrified moment passes. Suddenly:
The door! They both bolt down the aisle toward the midsection doors
Davey bursts through the door into his father's arms.
Dad ---
(embracing his son) Davey --- Davey pulls free and glances at his watch.
Dad, there's a bomb in the back that's due to go off in less than a minute.
C'mon, we'll get out of here --- He slams the ceckpit door closed and locks it, turning ba to the small side window, fumbling with the catch to open
George is pulling at the exit door. He turns to Eunice.
It won't open. Not with the cabin pressurized.
They whirl and dash for the cockpit door. The digital counter on the bomb ticks dispassionately on,
162 Hal finally gets the side window open and reaches for his son.
c'mon, out you go ---
(staring at the small window You'll never fit --- Suddenly there's a pounding at the door and screams from the other side.
Open up! .
(grabbing his son) Don't worry about me. Just get out of here.
(struggling to ° voyage tee bimself) | SN ape a ei care tate ONE LENBUE Be ae ie te ARNE ne oe Lathe sty He shoves his son screaming and fighting through the smal window. :
No -~ !

Davey slips through the cockpit window, sliding down the cave side of the airplane, and hitting the wing, breaking fall. He grabs onto the aluminum, trying to hold on, the slipstream of the speeding jet dragging him back and off. He hits the soft ground at the side of the runway as the plane careens across the grass Davey shakes his head to clear it, leaps to his feet, running after the plane which is quickly accelerating int the night.
ro o w

Dad, Dad -- ! And the plane continues to gain speed, quickly outdistanc the small running boy, roaring off into the night, swallo up by darkness. Davey keeps running after it anyway. The night is suddenly shattered by a huge explosion, a fireball of incredible brightness and size roaring up out of the blackness. The concussion blows Davey back and off his feet, bending the grass and bushes around him almost their breaking point. He picks himself slowly up off the ground, staring down t runway at a night that has suddenly become brighter than day, an enormous fireball of high-octane aviation fuel climbing into the night sky.
(in a shattered voice) Dad! Tears stream down his cheeks. (X)
Dad -- !

He suddenly stops, staring into the almost blinding incandescence of the fireball. A tall, handsome figure of aman backlit in burning orange, shimmering against the night sky and the rising fumes of the fire is walking toward him slowly out of the conflagration. Davey just stares at the apparition, watching the glowing outline of the figure drawing closer and closer to him, something teasingly, wonderfully familiar about it. And then he recognizes the figure, that jaunty, confident walk, the insolent slouch, that aggressive lowered curve the shoulder.

(staring in disbelief) Jack? And now the figure is closer, almost recognizable...and i looks just like the super spy, everything about him is th same, the walk, the carriage, even the faint smile Davey can barely make out on the man's face.

Jack! And his father stoops down and grabs him up in his arms, swinging him about, cradling the crying boy's face in his son tant eps sian scene SE ODT SHOU AR », athe, and there what seems Tike sevéra eee s  piharty Her Holds Him Sue r a little bit away from him, using his free hand to wipe Davey's tears away, and brushing aside a few of his own a the same time. He smiles almost wistfully at his son. Davey gets his first real good look at his father; sure enough, it's Hal Osborne, his face smudged with the smoke of the wreck, his hair singed by the fire, discheviled an battered, nothing very romantic about him at all. Davey looks at him hard, real joy and relief flooding his small boy's face. He throws his arms around his father's neck again, holding him as tightly as he can.
Dad! How'd you get out?
Jack Flack always gets out.

we 163 CONTINUED - 3 163 And they stand like that, father and son tearfully embracing as the plane burns away in the b.g., Kim and Marilyn Gardener racing toward them in the f.g., the sound of fire engines and police cars tearing across the tarmac toward them, already renting the night air and somehow interrupting this very private, very personal moment between father and son.
